author: CapnRex101
title: 7868 - Mace Windu's Jedi Starfighter
review:
This set surprised me, when I first saw it I expected it to be boring, only really good for the Tactical Droid. But it is so much more than that. This is an excellent set, it has all you need for a great battle. The figures are good, but it is the vehicles which won me over.

Box/Instructions

The box shows Mace Windu's starfighter flying low across a barren landscape, possibly Geonosis, under attack by two STAPs (Single Trooper Aerial Platform) and a Flitknot Speeder. Two of the Jedi Starfighter's missiles have been launched and are heading for the Tactical Droid as the STAPs fire their laser cannons.

In my set the instructions were correct and I had no missing pieces.

Parts

There are a few nice parts in this set, such as of course the Tactical Droid's combined head and torso piece. There are also several flat pieces in dark red, a fairly rare colour and quite a few nice deep blue slopes, which I like. I love the printing on all of the Astromech droids, and this one (R8-B7) is also very nice.

Minifigures

There are five minifigures in this set, Mace Windu, who is useful for people who did not get the Republic Attack Shuttle from 2009, two battle droids which are always welcome, the new Astromech unit R8-B7, who's paint scheme is very vibrant and interesting, and the incredible Tactical Droid, who looks absolutely wonderful, particularly aboard the Flitknot Speeder. The Tactical Droid is TX-20 (as seen in 'Innocents of Ryloth') but could also be the tactical droid seen speaking to Asajj Ventress in the episode 'The Hidden Enemy'.

The build

Firstly let me say, if you don't like stickers (I don't mind them, but I prefer pieces to be printed) then you may not enjoy building this set much, as there are a lot of stickers, on the speeder alone there are seven stickers! This set took me about thirty minutes to assemble and once you were past the tricky sticker applications, it was plain sailing. I like how the STAPs are constructed, but beyond that there are few interesting building techniques.

The completed model

When you get it all together, the set looks amazing, the inclusion of not just one, but two STAPs is welcome, as is the brilliant Flitknot Speeder (I just love the seat). But the main attraction is the spectacular starfighter, it is extremely accurate to the one seen in the Clone Wars episode from season two 'R2 Come Home' and the colours are lovely. I like the inclusion of four flick fire missiles underneath the fighter, which fire two at a time. The figures look great on all of the vehicles (especially R8-B7 in the fighter) and all together this makes for a great set.

Summary

I have to say I expected little from this set, but I am pleasantly surprised! The set makes for a good battle alone, but with some other sets, such as the Battle For Geonosis this could be very useful. With great display and play opportunities this set is just fantastic.


Overall - 10/10

author: EtudeTheBadger
title: Windu Rides Again!
review:
After a short period of waiting, I got this set today at ye olde LEGO Shop, and sadly it will be one of my last for a while. Ah well. At least I'm going out on a high, because this set is rather superb!

Building the Set and Pros

First off, yes - it's ANOTHER Jedi Starfighter, but with LEGO keeping the designs this varied, who can complain? This time around, it's Mace Windu and his highly colourful droid R8-B7! Along for the trip are a small entourage of droids and a series of speedercraft.

Building the Jedi Fighter is easy and fun, and being the owner of a LOT of Jedi fighters, I'm glad to see another variation. This ship has double the number of missiles compared to earlier versions, they fire differently, and the mechanism to fire them with is inspired - really! Flick fire missiles work best with a mechanism!

I also love the colours, with a lot of darker versions of the red and green hues. While it's not the chunkiest fighter around - that would have to be Ahsoka's - it still has some weight, and is very moveable. R8-B7 completes the ship with his dark blue dome, and he's held in place with studs so he won't fall out during barrel rolls. The Republic emblem and the control panel are also transfers rather than stickers! Mace Windu returns from the Republic Attack Shuttle, and he's great if you don't have him already.

The STAPs are pretty much copies of the one included in the 2008 AT-TE set, but they were enjoyable builds. The Speeder is very good - I like the design, the seat... and the Tactical Droid - awesome! Hope there's more of him to come - I'd love an army of these guys!

Cons

It's a great set, but it has some drawbacks, I'm afraid. Ahem. Stickers. Yep. LOTS of 'em. To make this set look its best, you'll have to stick on the details. The Speeder is the prime example - a total of seven stickers are needed to complete its look, and it's a good look. But why can't we have printed parts?! The same with the Fighter and even the STAPs! THe stickers for the Fighter were a pain, especially the fuselage stickers. Sigh. At least they went on... after a bit of adjusting.

Secondly, Mace's Fighter has no guns! Really! Maybe that's why it has more missiles - to compensate for this! LEGO could easily have included some cannons, and this just puzzles me...

Pros and Cons at a Glance

  • PROS
  • Great to build
  • Fighter looks super
  • Speeder is awesome
  • Tactical Droid kicks butt
  • R8-B7 is a must-have!
  • Mace Windu - he's just cool
  • Some good use of transfers
  • More Battle Droids for an army
  • CONS
  • Too many stickers - STILL!
  • Fighter has no guns - uh?!
Overall, even with the negatives taken into consideration, this a great set, and worth having for R8 alone.

author: Redbullgivesuwind
title: Good set let down by a few silly errors
review:
This is another star fighter from the Clone Wars TV series and it’s great to see Mace Windu finally able to get involved in the battles. So with high expectations after seeing it on TV and the reviews on here and YouTube I took the plunge and bought it. In all fairness to Lego the package arrived in two days faster than the promised three to five days.

The box is very dynamic and shows Maces fighter swooping over a desert planet (Ryloth?) to tackle the tactical droid and the two STAAPs. This has really become one of the strong points of Lego with the box art really looking fantastic and i hope they keep it up. The box is also smaller than the previous boxes which will help with storage and also the environment, by using fewer trees.

So, to the characters. The droids and Mace have appeared in several sets and are pretty bog standard with the detailing on Mace looking very good and it’s nice to start forming a Jedi council. The main reason to buy this set is for the two new characters R8-B7 and the tactical droid. R8-B7 is again fantastic looking and the colouring of gold and dark blue makes it stand out against the sea of R2's that we have had before and it is a great touch to have the Jedi with their own droids, such as Plo Koon's. Even if you don’t want this set I’d pick up the droid from it you will not be let down.

The tactical droid on the other hand was a massive disappointment. The paintings is really hit and miss with the eyes failing to be painted and the lining across the head really wonky. It’s perhaps a point that they are hand painted (I doubt it though) and this may excuse it to an extent but it’s still frustrating to think I'm going to have to do this myself. Also the arms are form the Battle Droids and the legs from the Super Battle Droids the body however the body is new and tiny. I was led to believe that this was a normal size and look at home with the other droids. Yet this is half the size of the rest of it and gives it a chimp look with a massive arm and legs and tiny body. Perhaps this is really obvious to people from the pictures yet they make it seem really large. With this small sixe when it is placed on the speeder it looks even stupider.

That said the speeder and the STAAPs are really good they do not take long to build and can be seen in the Blue Shadow episode at the start. They did not take long and even though they both had stickers (bane of my life!) were still easy to build. The speeders shape and aerodynamics make it very swooshable.

The star fighter is a normal build and very similar to Anakins at the rear and closer to Plo Koons at the front. The colouring matches both the TV and the Hasbro Version and it stands out very well. The build again is not difficult and took only fifteen minutes. The stickers however took five minutes to get right and I am still not happy with them. I get that it’s to keep the cost down and they would be left with printed bricks that were no good to anyone but at least maybe ridge them so we can line them up correctly. So while I am in annoyed mode there is one more thing I feel lets this ship down and its flick fire missiles. They are not as bad as the stupid giant push missiles that ruined both the Naboo star fighter and Slave II but I see no point to them what so ever and they don’t add anything to this set, even detracting from what is a very good looking ship. They form a box on the bottom that ruins its sleek shape and once it was built I got rid of it and turned them in to guns.

I struggled to give this four stars it’s really only a three and a half as it for me is let down by too many stickers, flick fire missiles and no guns and a poorly proportioned droid. However at £35 it is great for the amount of stuff that you get and I cannot help but think if this was in the Autumn set it would be closer to £45. So I would get it but prepare to feel a bit frustrated at the same time over some really easily fixable stuff.

author: parchioso
title: Mace got a better Starfighter than Plo Koon's
review:
When someone is seen buying this Mace Windu's Jedi Starfighter set, many would think that they are targetting the R8-B7 astromech droid and the Tactical Droid TX-20, yes, these two items are bringing values to the set, but I got this set for simply what it is, the Starfighter.

 

While the Plo Koon's Starfighter was a little disappointing, the color combination makes this Starfighter looks better, though the use of stickers is still a bad thing for me (despite being a better sticker set), the movement of the wings in this Starfighter seems to be rather limited, and the vehicle is poorly armed, with only a missile launcher at the bottom of the cabin.

 

Another feature which is highlighted in the manual is the placeholder of the lightsaber, but in two pieces, which is a strange idea.

 

But after all, it is a good looking Starfighter, plus the R8-B7, TX-20, a nice Separatist speeder, and two STAPs (Single Trooper Aerial Platform), it is a good value set to get, and a must get if you a Starfighter fan.

 

However, this set is another sign that sticker wedges for Starfighters is the norm now, I understand that stickers are common in lego, but for Starfighters, they should really consider a printed wedge as it is the essence of the vehicle.

 

The ironic part of this set is Mace, despite being a wonderful character, the minifig is also available in 8019, so I am not sure if the minifig would become the focus of the set.

 

I have a pictorial review at: http://brickand.me/2011/02/05/Lego7868MaceWindusJediStarfighterStickerWedgeAgain.aspx

author: LEGOSLUG
title: Blast off with Mace Windu´s Starfighter!
review:
Heres the Pros and Con of the set 7868, Mace Windu´s Jedi Starfighter.


The Minifigures:

Mace Windu from the Clone Wars, as seen in set 8019,Republic Attack Shuttle.

R8-D7- Mace´s trusty astromech, which is unique to the set fits in the astromech socket. 2 Battle Droids on STAPs (Single Trooper Aerial Platform). And, the Tactical Droid, TX-20 with a new droid torso and head design.


The Build:

The build is relatively simple, there are no mistakes in the building instructions, and every thing in the booklet is easy to understand.

The build doesn´t take long, but its not over in 2mins.

The 2 Battle Droids also come with extra arms, turned, so they can hold the blasters included. the lightsaber clip on the back of the wings, in 2 pieces.


Pros

* Cool new Minifigures
* Cool Starfighter
* Cheaper than other LEGO Star Wars sets.

Cons

* A few stickers, I had to adjust the positioning on a few.
* Cockpit roof doesn´t have a hinge, it just clips on.

All in All it is an Awesome set, buy it if you are a fan of LEGO Star Wars, it doesn´t disappoint. A Must Have for any serious collector.

 

LEGOSLUG

 

P.S. Please see and rate my other Reviews and Bricklists.

author: Bondady
title: The Man in Black is Back and he has some new tricks
review: Mace Windu, that moron that we all remeber from episode 1, 2, and 3 and now more recently some of the cartoon series. And he hasn't gotten better since. They set up his character to be a jerk so it is. But despite all that you have to like the new set he is in. There have been multiple other jedi fighter sets but I think this is one that was got peoples attention. Why? Because it looked differnet. I don't mean the design but the content it came with. I know I had been waiting for the tactical droid for ages. And to get two more high flying staps was just to good too be true. Luckly it still is true. This set doesn't challenge you though. It is an easy set that everyone with a jedi star fighter has built. So over all it isn't that great but hey, I'm still going to use. So in the long run, don't shake before you try it. Bondady signing off.

author: IamLegoman1475
title: Starfighter Wars, Episode IV: A New...Starfighter...
review:
This set is the 4th Starfighter released for the Clone Wars (Anikan, Ashoka, Plo Koon), but 7th starfighter overall (Obi Wan's Starfighter and the UCS version) This is my first starfighter, and I think it looks good. The figures, especially the Tactical Droid look good, along with R8-D7. Windu looks good, being CW and all, even if he has no printing on the back.

 

 The ship has the same pattern the other fighters have with the wings clipped on. It's a good way to get it on, as I can't imagine it being any different. The flickfires are perfect here as they are easy to fire, easy to take out. The saber is holded on the back, but it's really difficult to get the saber out without knocking the engine off. The vehicle for the Tactical Droid looks alright. The STAPS are good, they being a first for me.

 

Pros

  • Allright design
  • Good figure and good printing
  • Good flick-fire missiles

Cons

  • The stickers. Seriously, they print a Republic logo, but they can't print a tiny one?
  • Pricing could've been $5 less, then again the ratio's about 12, so take it or leave it.

 

Overall, I recommend this set for anyone who just wants to have a Starfighter, but doesn't want Plo Koon's, or wait for the next one.

author: DarthZared
title: The most fun possible for £35!
review:
7868-1 Mace Windu's Jedi Starfighter is a 2011 £35 January wave set. This set is a little expensive but is worth it for the playability.

Box/Instructions

Lego always have mouth-watering box decorations and the instructions are nice and easy to follow. The back of the box is a little cramped design-wise but it is still tempting!

Parts

Being a KFOL, I don't rate sets on parts and this set isn't exciting. No parts that I can see are new, but it is a nice parts pack nonetheless.

Minifigures

Mace Windu's CW variation has been criticized but it is a great figure in truth. The battle droids are nothing special, but one downside is the fact that they don't come with blasters. Last but definitely not least is the Tactical Droid, who has a superb head and torso piece combo. His figure is amazing, and should be made more commercially available.

The build

The build of the starfighter is a little basic with standard techniques. It is still different from other starfighters from TCW as it includes a poor quad-flick missile system underneath. Not forgetting the STAPS, which haven't been changed since the promo pack but are a nice playability touch. The droid speeder is amazing, as I love the tiled seat and the sleek design.

The completed model

This set's four separate parts are great to be played with, and look nice on display if you have a little scene/battle going on on your shelf!

Summary

Overall this set is great, although a little pricey, but is worth it whatever age or whatever aspect of Star Wars you enjoy!

author: TheJediWookie
title: Okay Minifigures and Build
review: The Mace Windu figure is great and to the best of my recollection, a rare figure at the time so it was cool to get him in a set. The other minifigures are fairly average. The set includes my only STAP fighters, a Seperatist speeder and my first Lego Jedi Starfighter. The build was quite simple so if you're looking for something challenging to build then this set isn't for you. Other than that, a fairly decent set for the price but wouldn't purchase at rrp. May the force be with you!
